newsitem.title: FRANCE: Court says Greece hit Jehovah's Witnesses rights.
newsitem.headline: Court says Greece hit Jehovah's Witnesses rights.

text.p: The European Court of Human Rights on Thursday ordered Greece to pay legal costs to four Jehovah's Witnesses, saying Athens' restrictions on opening places of worship violated their freedom of religion.

The Court ordered Greece to pay four million drachmas ($16,700) in legal costs to the four men -- Titos Manoussakis, Constantin Makridakis, Kyriakos Baxevanis and Vassilios Hatzakis -- for refusing them permission to open a place of prayer.

Since March 1983 they have been awaiting an answer from the Education and Religion Ministry to their demand that a hall be earmarked for prayers in Heraklion on the island of Crete. Greek law requires that all sites of worship have permission to open.
They were prosecuted after starting prayers, acquitted in a first trial in 1987 but sentenced on appeal in 1990 and by the Supreme Court in 1991.

"The Court noted...that the relevant Greek legislation allows far-reaching interference by the political, administrative and ecclesiastical authorities with the exercise of religious freedom," the Strasbourg-based European court said in its ruling.

It said that the Greek authorisation procedure was used "to impose rigid, or indeed prohibitive conditions on the practice of religious beliefs by certain non-orthodox movements, in particular Jehovah's Witnesses".

"The right to freedom of religion as guaranteed under the Convention (on human rights) excluded any discretion on the part of the State to determine whether religious beliefs or the means used to express such beliefs were legitimate," it said.
